Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Overnight temperatures in 20F on 01/15/21 consolidated top 6in of snowpack which contributed to high snow slope stability. The deeper layer did not freeze through and the ice layer in 4in depth has potential for stability degradation.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;

Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Snowmobile tracks on slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This slope avalanched approximately 5 days ago, likely from a sledder.

Variability abound in slab presence. Faceting throughout snowpack - cross loaded ramps had stiffer slab around 1F, and lower areas the slab would be 4F, about 15cm under the surface with sandbox below. Both ECT and CT, produced no results, columns would crumble at the end of tests a sign of the sandboxing.

User.name: Steve Reynaud

Pit_Observation.activities: Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: We viewed a small human triggered(snow machine) avalanche on a similar slope about 1/4 mile to the North of our location. The small slab failed on the buried surface hoar and facet layer at 195cm. A decline in slope angle did not allow the slab to run more than about 30 feet downhill. We did not get propagation in an ECT we performed just below the slide site.

Pit is adjacent to avalanche: flank; Near Avalanche at;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Profile from natural avalnache triggered by a cornice fall. Easily over 1000 feet wide, but hard to tell if it was all one slide or many sympathetic ones. The very fragile crust at 25-26 cm seems to be what is helping these slides fracture across such long distances despite such a soft slab.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
HS was deeper than 250 cms. Lot's of recent slab avalanche activity around this area, on all aspects (photos attached).
Faceted graupel layer at 135cms, hypothesized to be the weak layer responsible for the west facing slab avalanches on the aprons of Mt. Zimmer (a couple appeared to be on slope angles around 35 deg or slightly less).
Pit dug in wind loaded area
No result in snowpack tests.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Near Avalanche at; Collapsing, widespread; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: 24 hours before I dug this pit skinners remotely triggered this slope from ridge crest ~5m away from crown.SS-ASr-R2-D2-O/G-80cm depth on 2-3mm rounding facets. I collapsed and cracked the hangfire minutes before I dug this pit. Cracks (10 meter radius) extended down to bed surface of avalanche ~80cm down from surface (30cm off ground). More photos and videos are available if wanted. ~23 cm of snow overnight following avalanche.

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
Collapsing, localized; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in a location protected from wind

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: First Test Slope below road on Teton Pass Access Road. Collapsed this slope on 12/22. Slope collapsed again today with 1.5meter crack radius. Quick pit on way out to investigate KB Ridge avalanche triggered remotely the day before. Strong variability in snow depth in this wind loaded (and previously stripped) location. Consistent failure on 2.5mm advanced facets buried on 12/11/20.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: SH Layer on top of MFC was sensitive on both ECT and CT, will be more reactive with more weight as well as slab cohesion to spur propagation.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Wind loading evident on slope above. Ground vegetated/grassy, surrounded by Larch trees, HS=80-105cm around pit. Location is ~20m above Rock Garden entrance traverse.

User.range: Banff, Yoho and Kootenay National Parks
User.name: Thomas Poitras

Location.range: Banff, Yoho and Kootenay National Parks
Location.name: Larch Top

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking;
Cracking; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: overcast and light snow until 1100am then clear; whumphing and cracking all elevations particularly in wind affected areas.

Dug on a slope that was lee to current SE storm winds and previous NE winds. Found numerous crusts in the top 1.5 meters and several layers of preserved stellar snowflakes in the top 50cms. No Surface Hoar. Did not get any notable results on the upper crusts or storm intensity changes. Had one 'hard' CT result on faceting grains above the major layer of frozen melt forms over a meter below the surface (88cms from the ground). I only noticed this RP result after I was done with my test so don't know the exact score. I tried to reproduce it in a CT, ECT, and DT without any repeat result on this layer.
Couldn't see higher elevation slopes due to clounds and snowfall. Identical test result of ECTP17 on similar layer of fx's above a fragile crust found on a NNE aspect nearby.
